summary: This document is a legal opinion prepared by French attorney William Julie regarding French extradition law, specifically addressing whether Ghislaine Maxwell could be extradited from France to the United States if she fled there while on bail. The opinion concludes that French law and the US-France extradition treaty do not prohibit the extradition of French nationals, and it is highly unlikely France would refuse extradition in Maxwell's case given her US citizenship, signed waiver, and diplomatic considerations. The document includes the opinion, the attorney's resume, and Maxwell's signed extradition waiver.

persons.name: William Julie
persons.role: Attorney at law, author of the opinion
persons.context: French attorney who authored the legal opinion on French extradition law for Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team. He is an expert in extradition and criminal law.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the extradition analysis. She is a dual US/French citizen detained pre-trial in the US on charges related to facilitating Jeffrey Epstein's sexual activities with minors. The opinion assesses her extradition risk if she fled to France.

persons.name: Olivier Laude
persons.context: French lawyer who instructed William Julie to draft the extradition opinion on behalf of Cohen & Gresser LLP, Maxwell's US counsel.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the individual with whom Maxwell allegedly facilitated sexual activities with minor girls from 1994 to 1997.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP, listed as Maxwell's counsel in her signed extradition waiver affidavit.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP, listed as Maxwell's counsel in her signed extradition waiver affidavit.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Judge before whom Ghislaine Maxwell swore her extradition waiver affidavit.

persons.name: Moukhtar Abliazov
persons.context: Mentioned as a prominent figure of the Kazakh opposition whose extradition to Russia was denied by France on political grounds, cited as a contrast to US extradition requests.

connections.description: William Julie was hired by Maxwell's legal team to provide a legal opinion on French extradition law to support her bail arguments.
Olivier Laude, acting on behalf of Maxwell's US counsel Cohen & Gresser, instructed William Julie to draft the extradition opinion.
Mark S. Cohen is listed as Maxwell's counsel in her signed extradition waiver affidavit.
Christian R. Everdell is listed as Maxwell's counsel in her signed extradition waiver affidavit.
The document states Maxwell's charges relate to her alleged role in sexual activities between Jeffrey Epstein and minor girls.

events.title: Bail hearing of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The US Government argued at Maxwell's bail hearing that France would not extradite a French citizen to the US, which was cited as a reason to deny bail due to flight risk.

events.title: Filing of Superseding Indictment
events.description: The Superseding Indictment (SI 20 Cr. 330) against Ghislaine Maxwell was filed, containing grand jury charges related to conspiracy, enticement, and transportation of minors.

events.title: Execution of Extradition Waiver
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell signed an affidavit irrevocably waiving her right to contest extradition from France to the US, intended to be used if she fled to France after bail release.

events.title: Signing of US-France Extradition Treaty
events.description: The Extradition Treaty between the United States and France was signed in Paris, governing extradition requests between the two countries.

locations: 75017 Paris (address of William Julie's law firm)
Metropolitan Detention Center, Brooklyn, New York
United States District Court, Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The legal opinion concludes that French law and the US-France extradition treaty do NOT prohibit the extradition of French nationals to the United States, contrary to claims made by the US Government at Maxwell's bail hearing.
Ghislaine Maxwell signed an irrevocable waiver of her right to contest extradition from France to the US, which her legal team argued would make extradition highly likely if she fled to France.

The opinion states that if Maxwell fled to France after violating bail, she would likely be placed in custody there during extradition proceedings, and the overall process could be completed expediently (within weeks).
The document reveals that Maxwell's French nationality and international ties were cited by the US court as grounds for denying her bail, due to perceived flight risk.

The opinion notes there is no precedent for the US seeking extradition of a dual French-US citizen from France, but argues diplomatic and practical factors would strongly favor extradition in Maxwell's unique case.
